While planting other trees or plant species can help mitigate some of the negative impacts of Ficus tree removal, it may not always be an effective solution. Here are a few reasons why replacing Ficus trees with other trees or plants may not always work:

1. Specific ecological relationships: As I mentioned earlier, Ficus trees often have specific ecological relationships with particular animals, such as fig wasps. These specific relationships have developed over time and may not be easily replaced by other tree species.

2. Soil and microclimate differences: Ficus trees have unique root systems and canopies, which can create specific soil and microclimate conditions that are conducive to other species. Removing Ficus trees and replacing them with new trees or plants may not create the same conditions or support the same ecosystem processes.

3. Cost and feasibility: Depending on the location and scale of Ficus tree removal, replanting with other trees or plants may be costly and logistically difficult. This can make it challenging to undertake large-scale restoration projects.

It is possible to mitigate the negative impacts of Ficus tree removal by planting other tree species and creating new habitats for animals, but it is important to carefully consider the ecological relationships and site-specific conditions before undertaking any restoration efforts. Ideally, conservation efforts should focus on preserving and protecting existing Ficus trees and their ecosystems, rather than trying to replace them after they have been lost.
